How about removing the looping from the code within the loop.
Now you have a single function that you can test in various
ways and check that you get the return that would end the
looping.

For instance:

public void looper ()
{
    boolean bRet = false;

    while (bRet == false)
    {
        bRet = doSomething(...);
    }
}

public boolean doSomething (...) { }

Now test doSomething sufficiently to stop it creating an infinite
loop.  Seems like it might work?

John.

----Original Message Follows----
I found a bug, so I want to write a test that exposes that bug.

How does one write a unit test that exposes an infinte loop?  Well, writing
one that exposes it isn't hard.  How do you expose it with out the test
hanging?

The only solution I can see is to use two threads, and set a maximum time
for the test to run.  While I've done it before, I really hate putting a
time-limit specific tests, as every system behaves differently, and they
behave differently at different times (it's that non-deterministic thing
that I didn't understand in college :)

Thanks for any input....

David Corbin
